{{Infobox Software | name = Central Desktop | logo = [[Image:CDLogo2010.GIF|180px]] | screenshot = [[Image:Central-desktop-dashboard.JPG|280px]] | caption = A dashboard view, seen within Central Desktop | developer = Central Desktop | operating_system = [[Cross-platform]] | genre = [[Collaborative software]] | website = [http://centraldesktop.com www.centraldesktop.com] }}
'''Central Desktop, Inc.''' is a privately held [[collaboration software]] company that is headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company's primary focus is providing a Software-as-a-Service collaboration tool to small and medium-sized businesses. The company and its products are most often compared to other wiki-based and project-centric solutions such as [[SharePoint]] and [[Basecamp (software)|Basecamp]].<ref>http://www.informationweek.com/news/software/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=206101113</ref> As of February 2009, the company serves more than 375,000 users worldwide with customers such as [[Gymboree]], [[Nielsen Company|Nielsen]], [[CBS]], [[Ritz-Carlton|The Ritz-Carlton]], [[Netflix]] and [[Harvard University]].<ref>http://www.pcworld.com/article/189948/central_desktops_20_upgrade_focuses_on_user_interface.html</ref>
==History==
The company was founded by CEO Isaac Garcia and CTO Arnulf Hsu in 2005. Prior to founding Central Desktop, Isaac and Arnulf started Upgradebase in 1997, a product data provider to the computer and consumer electronics industry, and Vendorbase in 1999, a B2B marketplace for computer resellers. Both companies were acquired by [[CNET Networks]] in 2002.<ref>http://www.sramanamitra.com/2009/02/03/central-desktop/</ref>
In December 2006, the company accused [[Google]] of unfairly competing against its own customers by bidding on keywords that Google held an interest in.<ref>http://cdblog.centraldesktop.com/2006/12/googles-silent-monopoly-or-how.html</ref> Google responded to the accusations on its own [[AdWords]] blog.<ref>http://adwords.blogspot.com/2006/12/google-advertising-on-adwords.html</ref>
Central Desktop received $7 million in first round funding from [[OpenView Venture Partners]] <ref>http://www.openviewpartners.com</ref> in April 2008.<ref>http://techcrunch.com/2008/04/16/central-desktop-takes-7-million/</ref>
==Products==
'''Central Desktop''' is offered in three editions - Workgroup, Enterprise and Community.<ref>http://www.cmswire.com/cms/document-management/central-desktop-saas-collaboration-now-available-on-intuit-app-center-005848.php</ref>
In February 2010, the company released version 2.0 of its software, Central Desktop 2.0. New features in Central Desktop 2.0 include an online file viewer that supports more than 200 different file types, improved wiki navigation and the ability to convert any file type into a downloadable PDF document.<ref>http://www.fiercecio.com/techwatch/story/central-desktop-unveils-2-0-upgrade/2010-02-23</ref>
Central Desktop product features include: * [[Wikis]] * [[WYSIWYG]] editing * [[Document management]] * Integrated [[Lucene]] search (full text searches for [[Microsoft Word|Word]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], [[PowerPoint]] and [[PDF]] files) * Online documents * [[Online spreadsheets]] * Task management * Project management * [[Discussion thread]]s * Online file viewer * [[Web conferencing]] * Workflow solutions * [[Microblogging]]
==See also== * [[Comparison of wiki software]] * [[List of collaborative software]] * [[Comparison of wiki farms]] * [[Online office suite]] * [[Cloud collaboration]] * [[Document collaboration]] * [[Document-centric collaboration]]
